message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Formal Synthesis of Stochastic Systems via Control Barrier Certificates
Paper Abstract: This paper focuses on synthesizing control policies for discrete-time\nstochastic control systems together with a lower bound on the probability that\nthe systems satisfy the complex temporal properties. The desired properties of\nthe system are expressed as linear temporal logic (LTL) specifications over\nfinite traces. In particular, our approach decomposes the given specification\ninto simpler reachability tasks based on its automata representation. We then\npropose the use of so-called \\emph{control barrier certificate} to solve those\nsimpler reachability tasks along with computing the corresponding controllers\nand probability bounds. Finally, we combine those controllers to obtain a\nhybrid control policy solving the considered problem. Under some assumptions,\nwe also provide two systematic approaches for uncountable and finite input sets\nto search for control barrier certificates. We demonstrate the effectiveness of\nthe proposed approach on a room temperature control and lane-keeping of a\nvehicle modeled as a four-dimensional single-track kinematic model. We compare\nour results with the discretization-based methods in the literature.\n
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's what I found about Linear Temporal Logic:

## Overview

Linear Temporal Logic (LTL) is a modal temporal logic with modalities referring to time.(no content)In LTL, one can encode formulae about the future of paths, for example that a condition will eventually be true, or a condition will be true until another fact becomes true.

## Applications and Uses

LTL formulas are commonly used to express constraints, specifications, or processes that a system should follow.(no content)The field of model checking aims to formally verify whether a system meets a given specification, and in automata-theoretic model checking, both the system and specification are expressed as finite-state machines to evaluate whether the system has the specified property.

## Types of Properties

There are two main types of properties that can be expressed using linear temporal logic: safety properties usually state that something bad never happens, while liveness properties state that something good keeps happening.(no content)For example, a safety property may require that an autonomous rover never drives over a cliff, or that a software product never allows a successful login with an incorrect password.

## Extensions

Parametric linear temporal logic extends LTL with variables on the until-modality. Additionally, there are time-constrained variants like metric temporal logic that extend LTL's capabilities for real-time systems.

Web search results for query: "Automata theory"

Links: [{"title":"Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata_theory"},{"title":"Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_Automata_Theory,_Languages,_and_Computation"},{"title":"Tree (automata theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(automata_theory)"},{"title":"Category:Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automata_theory"},{"title":"Theory of computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_computation"},{"title":"Cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Krohn-Rhodes theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krohn–Rhodes_theory"},{"title":"Learning automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_automaton"},{"title":"Hybrid automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_automaton"},{"title":"Finite-state machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_machine"}]

## Automata Theory

Automata theory is the study of abstract machines and automata, as well as the computational problems that can be solved using them.(no content)It is a theory in theoretical computer science with close connections to cognitive science and mathematical logic.

### Fundamental Concepts

An automaton is an abstract self-propelled computing device which follows a predetermined sequence of operations automatically.(no content)An automaton with a finite number of states is called a finite automaton (FA) or finite-state machine (FSM).(no content)Automata theory is closely related to formal language theory, and in this context, automata are used as finite representations of formal languages that may be infinite.

### Applications and Importance

Automata play a major role in the theory of computation, compiler construction, artificial intelligence, parsing and formal verification.

### Historical Development

The theory of abstract automata was developed in the mid-20th century, and in 1956 the publication of "Automata Studies" collected work by major scientists including Claude Shannon, John von Neumann, and others. With this publication, "automata theory emerged as a relatively autonomous discipline".

The field encompasses several important variants and specialized areas, including finite-state machines, cellular automata, hybrid automata, and various theoretical frameworks for understanding computational systems and their capabilities.

Web search results for query: "Reachability analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Reachability analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis"},{"title":"Reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability"},{"title":"Reachability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_problem"},{"title":"Context-free language reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_language_reachability"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Petri net - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net"},{"title":"International Conference on Reachability Problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Reachability_Problems"},{"title":"Reaching definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaching_definition"},{"title":"Petri net unfoldings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net_unfoldings"},{"title":"Control-flow graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-flow_graph"}]

Based on the search results, here's what reachability analysis is:

## Overview

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system consisting of local entities that communicate by exchanging messages.

## Key Components

The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.(no content)The transition graph can be used for checking general design flaws of the protocol, and also for verifying that the sequences of service interactions by the entities correspond to the requirements given by the global service specification of the system.

## Challenges

A significant challenge in reachability analysis is the "state space explosion" problem, where if two entities of a protocol have 100 states each and the medium may include 10 types of messages, the number of global states in the reachability graph can be bound by 100 million.

## Tools and Applications

A number of tools have been developed to automatically perform reachability analysis and model checking on the reachability graph, such as the SPIN model checker.

Reachability analysis is widely applicable and appears in various contexts, including infinite state systems, rewriting systems, dynamical and hybrid systems, logic and verification, and different computational models such as Petri nets and communicating automata.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, here's information about kinematic models for vehicles:

## Overview

Kinematics studies the geometrical aspects of motion of physical objects independent of forces that set them in motion.(no content)Kinematics equations are constraint equations that characterize the geometric configuration of an articulated mechanical system.

## Vehicle Dynamics and Kinematics

Vehicle dynamics is the study of vehicle motion, e.g., how a vehicle's forward movement changes in response to driver inputs, propulsion system outputs, ambient conditions, air/surface/water conditions, etc.(no content)Vehicle dynamic behavior can be analyzed using approaches ranging from a simple spring mass system, through a three-degree of freedom (DoF) bicycle model, to large degree of complexity using multibody system simulation packages.

## Applications in Motion Planning

In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.(no content)Similar formulas determine the positions of vehicles such as cars or boats, where kinematic equations model the movement of the system.

The kinematic model of a vehicle is a simplified mathematical representation that describes how a vehicle's position and orientation change over time based on its control inputs, without considering the forces that produce the motion.

Web search results for query: "Lane keeping"

Links: [{"title":"Automated lane keeping systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_Lane_Keeping_Systems"},{"title":"Lane departure warning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_departure_warning_system"},{"title":"Lane centering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_centering"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lane_keeping_assist"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about lane keeping systems:

## Lane Keeping Overview

Lane keeping, also known as lane centering assist, lane assist, auto steer or autosteer, is an advanced driver-assistance system that keeps a road vehicle centered in the lane, relieving the driver of the task of steering.

## Types of Lane Keeping Systems

There are several variations of lane keeping technology:

- Lane keeping assist (LKA/LKS) systems which warn the driver and, with no response, automatically take steps to ensure the vehicle stays in its lane
- Lane centering assist (LCA) systems which assist in oversteering, keeping the car centered in the lane, and asking the driver to take over in challenging situations
- Automated lane keeping systems (ALKS), also described as traffic jam chauffeurs, is an autonomous driving system that doesn't require driver supervision on motorways

## How It Works

A camera, mounted at the top of the windshield just above the rear-view mirror, scans the road ahead in a 40-degree radius, picking up the dotted white lines used to divide lane boundaries on the highway. The computer recognizes that the driver is "locked into" a particular lane, monitors how sharp a curve is, and uses factors such as yaw and vehicle speed to calculate the steering input required.

## Safety Benefits

One of the main causes of single vehicle crashes and frontal crashes is lane departure. The goal of the lateral support systems (LSS) is to help to avoid such crashes.

Links: [{"title":"Temperature control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperature_control"},{"title":"Thermostat - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermostat"},{"title":"HVAC control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HVAC_control_system"},{"title":"Proportional–integral–derivative controller","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional–integral–derivative_controller"},{"title":"Setpoint (control system) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Setpoint_(control_system)"},{"title":"Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heating,_ventilation,_and_air_conditioning"},{"title":"Margaret A. Wilcox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_A._Wilcox"},{"title":"Tormenta Stadium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tormenta_Stadium"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"}]

## Temperature Control System

Based on the search results, here's an overview of temperature control systems:

### What is a Temperature Control System?

A home thermostat is an example of a closed control loop that continuously measures the current room temperature and compares this to a desired user-defined setpoint, and controls a heater and/or air conditioner to increase or decrease the temperature to meet the desired setpoint.

### Applications

Thermostats are used in any device or system that heats or cools to a setpoint temperature, with examples including building heating, central heating, air conditioners, HVAC systems, water heaters, as well as kitchen equipment including ovens and refrigerators and medical and scientific incubators.

### Types of Control Mechanisms

Temperature control systems can use different sensor types:
- Mechanical thermostats commonly use bimetallic strips, converting a temperature change into mechanical displacement, to actuate control of the heating or cooling sources.
- Electronic thermostats use a thermistor or other semiconductor sensor, processing temperature change as electronic signals, to control the heating or cooling equipment.

### Advanced Control Methods

Further enhancements using the accumulated error signal (integral) and the rate at which the error is changing (derivative) are used to form more complex PID controllers, which is the form usually seen in industrial settings and more advanced consumer products.

Temperature control systems are fundamental to maintaining comfort and safety across residential, industrial, and commercial applications.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both in the natural and behavioral sciences, and is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both in the natural and behavioral sciences, and is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Stochastic control"

Links: [{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Category:Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Stochastic_control"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk%3AStochastic_control"},{"title":"Stochastic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_process"},{"title":"Pontryagin's maximum principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontryagin's_maximum_principle"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Anthony Tether - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Tether"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory?amp="}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of stochastic control:

## Definition

Stochastic control (or stochastic optimal control) is a sub field of control theory that deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system.

## Key Characteristics

A stochastic control problem is one in which the evolution of the state variables is subjected to random shocks from outside the system.(no content)In typical stochastic control problems, it is assumed that there exist random noise and disturbances in the model and the controller, and the control design must take into account these random deviations.

## Applications and Historical Development

The field of stochastic control has developed greatly since the 1970s, particularly in its applications to finance. Robert Merton used stochastic control to study optimal portfolios of safe and risky assets.

## Mathematical Tools

In continuous time, Itô's equation is the main tool of analysis. Additionally, the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function. Its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem which, once known, can be used to obtain the optimal control.

## Related Concepts

The separation principle is one of the fundamental principles of stochastic control theory, which states that the problems of optimal control and state estimation can be decoupled under certain conditions.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of the analysis:

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Formal Synthesis of Stochastic Systems via Control Barrier Certificates" and extracted 9 key triples:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: Contribution (the paper proposes novel methods)

### Key Technologies & Methodologies Identified

**Concepts Used:**
1. **Linear temporal logic** - Specification language for expressing temporal properties
2. **Stochastic control** - Addresses control systems with probabilistic guarantees
3. **Control theory** - Foundational control design principles
4. **Reachability analysis** - Decomposition method for solving specifications
5. **Automata theory** - Used to represent and decompose LTL specifications
6. **Kinematics** - Vehicle motion modeling in applications

**Tasks/Applications:**
7. **Automated Lane Keeping Systems** - Demonstrates practical application
8. **Temperature control** - Another experimental validation domain

**Novel Contribution:**
9. **Control barrier certificate** - The key novel method proposed for solving reachability tasks with probability bounds

### Validation Results
✅ All checks passed:
- Paper type correctly classified as "contribution"
- All 9 triples have proper entity types and relations
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and accessible
- Validation requirements met: at least 1 "uses" relation and 1 "proposes" relation present

The output JSON file has been successfully updated and validated.
